questions.text: Match the following suture materials with their characteristics related to absorption and tissue reactivity:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Silk : Braided or twisted multifilament, can be coated or uncoated, and derived from natural protein raw silk. It shows significant strength loss when wet and undergoes fibrous encapsulation in the body, being absorbed slowly over 1-2 years, matching with characteristic
  • • Silk
  • • Plain Catgut : Derived from collagen of sheep or cattle and is absorbed rapidly through phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 7-10 days, fitting characteristic
  • • Plain Catgut
  • • Chromic Catgut : Tanned with chromium salts to resist degradation, with an absorption timeline extended to 90 days, aligning with characteristic
  • • Chromic Catgut
  • • Polyglyconate : A monofilament suture material that maintains strength for an extended period but is eventually absorbed in about 180 days, corresponding with characteristics.
  • • Polyglyconate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When choosing suture materials for surgical procedures, it is important to consider the material's tissue reactivity, rate of strength loss when wet, and the timeline for absorption, to ensure optimal healing and minimize complications related to suture material.
  • ➤ When choosing suture materials for surgical procedures, it is important to consider the material's tissue reactivity, rate of strength loss when wet, and the timeline for absorption, to ensure optimal healing and minimize complications related to suture material.

questions.text: Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) involves measuring plasma concentrations of drugs to determine whether the levels are within the therapeutic range. For TDM to be clinically useful, which of the following criteria should be fulfilled?

options.label: A
options.text: There should be a good relationship between plasma concentration and drug dosage

options.label: B
options.text: The relationship between plasma drug concentration and therapeutic response and/or toxicity should be poor

options.label: D
options.text: When the clinical response cannot be easily monitored

questions.correct_answer: D. When the clinical response cannot be easily monitored
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) When the clinical response cannot be easily monitored

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TDM is particularly useful in managing drugs with narrow therapeutic windows, where dosing must be precise to avoid toxicity but adequate to ensure effectiveness.
  • ➤ It is especially critical when direct measurement of clinical response is challenging or when drugs have serious associated toxicities at slightly higher concentrations.

His mother reports that he sustained a thorn prick injury to his leg while playing in a field a week ago. The site of injury is slightly swollen and tender. Which empirical antibiotic therapy would be most appropriate to initiate for this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pediatric infections following a penetrating injury like a thorn prick, choose antibiotics like Amoxicillin + Clavulanate that cover both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. This approach ensures comprehensive treatment while promoting antimicrobial stewardship
  • ➤ For pediatric infections following a penetrating injury like a thorn prick, choose antibiotics like Amoxicillin + Clavulanate that cover both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: Which of these statements is true about components of vision 2020? Cataract surgery should be performed at primary level Retinal surgery should be performed at tertiary level Need to develop 10 centre of excellence at tertiary level and 100 training centre at advanced tertiary level Ophthalmia neonatorum is included in childhood blindness Primary vision center covers a population of 50000
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vision 2020 aims to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020 through infrastructure development, intervention strategies, and the provision of eye care services at different levels. Cataract surgery is performed at the secondary level, while highly specialized procedures like retinal surgery are conducted at tertiary level eye care centers. The plan includes the establishment of Centers of Excellence (COEs) at an advanced tertiary level, each catering to a population of 50 million, to provide specialized care and expertise in ophthalmology. Ophthalmia neonatorum, a significant cause of childhood blindness, is included in efforts to eliminate avoidable causes of blindness in children by the year 2020. Primary vision centers typically cover a population of 50,000, serving as the frontline in providing basic eye care services and identifying individuals in need of further treatment or surgery.
  • ➤ Vision 2020 aims to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020 through infrastructure development, intervention strategies, and the provision of eye care services at different levels.
  • ➤ Cataract surgery is performed at the secondary level, while highly specialized procedures like retinal surgery are conducted at tertiary level eye care centers.
  • ➤ The plan includes the establishment of Centers of Excellence (COEs) at an advanced tertiary level, each catering to a population of 50 million, to provide specialized care and expertise in ophthalmology.
  • ➤ Ophthalmia neonatorum, a significant cause of childhood blindness, is included in efforts to eliminate avoidable causes of blindness in children by the year 2020.
  • ➤ Primary vision centers typically cover a population of 50,000, serving as the frontline in providing basic eye care services and identifying individuals in need of further treatment or surgery.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department with a sudden onset of seizures. His medical history is unremarkable, and there has been no prior incidence of seizures. On examination, his blood pressure is notably elevated at 200/140 mm Hg in the right arm. However, when attempting to palpate the femoral pulses, they are not detectable. Based on the presentation and physical findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta is a condition that can present with high blood pressure in the upper extremities and diminished or absent pulses in the lower extremities. The presence of seizures in this context may be secondary to the hypertension or an associated condition such as a cerebral aneurysm.
  • ➤ Coarctation of the aorta is a condition that can present with high blood pressure in the upper extremities and diminished or absent pulses in the lower extremities.
  • ➤ The presence of seizures in this context may be secondary to the hypertension or an associated condition such as a cerebral aneurysm.

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: 1-1.5 cms behind the posterior end of the middle turbinate

options.label: D
options.text: 1-1.5 cms behind the anterior end of the middle turbinate

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-1.5 cms behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recognition of the anatomical position of the nasolacrimal duct in relation to the turbinates, is crucial for the assessment and management of lacrimal system disorders.
  • ➤ The recognition of the anatomical position of the nasolacrimal duct in relation to the turbinates, is crucial for the assessment and management of lacrimal system disorders.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, hard of hearing, while riding his motorbike met with a head-on collision with the truck on a national highway. He was thrown off the motorbike and fell down with an impact on his back a few metres away from the accident site. He was received in casualty. X-ray pictures taken showed multiple fractures of the left scapula. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Suprascapular artery passes above the suprascapular notch

options.label: B
options.text: Suprascapular nerve arises at Erb's point

options.label: C
options.text: If suprascapular nerve is injured at spinoglenoid notch medial rotation of arm is affected

options.label: D
options.text: Articular branches to acromioclavicular joint arises from suprascapular nerve proximal to suprascapular notch

questions.correct_answer: C. If suprascapular nerve is injured at spinoglenoid notch medial rotation of arm is affected
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) If Suprascapular Nerve is injured at Spinoglenoid Notch medial rotation of arm is affected

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If Suprascapular Nerve is Injured at Spinoglenoid Notch Medial Rotation of Arm is Affected:
  • ➤ If Suprascapular Nerve is Injured at Spinoglenoid Notch Medial Rotation of Arm is Affected:
  • ➤ If Suprascapular Nerve is Injured at Spinoglenoid Notch Medial Rotation of Arm is Affected:
  • ➤ The suprascapular nerve primarily innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles . These muscles are involved in the abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder , respectively. If the suprascapular nerve is injured at the spinoglenoid notch, it would predominantly affect the infraspinatus muscle , leading to difficulties in lateral rotation of the arm , not medial rotation. This statement is incorrect . Injury to the suprascapular nerve at the spinoglenoid notch would impact lateral rotation , not medial rotation.
  • ➤ The suprascapular nerve primarily innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles . These muscles are involved in the abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder , respectively.
  • ➤ innervates
  • ➤ supraspinatus
  • ➤ infraspinatus muscles
  • ➤ involved
  • ➤ abduction
  • ➤ lateral rotation
  • ➤ shoulder
  • ➤ If the suprascapular nerve is injured at the spinoglenoid notch, it would predominantly affect the infraspinatus muscle , leading to difficulties in lateral rotation of the arm , not medial rotation.
  • ➤ predominantly affect
  • ➤ infraspinatus muscle
  • ➤ leading
  • ➤ difficulties
  • ➤ lateral rotation
  • ➤ arm
  • ➤ This statement is incorrect . Injury to the suprascapular nerve at the spinoglenoid notch would impact lateral rotation , not medial rotation.
  • ➤ incorrect
  • ➤ impact lateral rotation

questions.text: Identify the correct statement:

options.label: A
options.text: Incisional hernia can occur at the site of previous surgical incisions and may present with a cough impulse

options.label: B
options.text: Epigastric hernia is related to surgical incisions and occurs below the umbilicus

options.label: C
options.text: Umbilical hernia will always require repair

options.label: D
options.text: Femoral hernia presents in men more commonly than women

questions.correct_answer: A. Incisional hernia can occur at the site of previous surgical incisions and may present with a cough impulse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It is important to correctly identify the type of hernia based on its location and relation to previous surgical sites to ensure proper surgical planning and patient counseling. Incisional hernias are related to previous surgeries, whereas epigastric, umbilical, and femoral hernias typically are not.
  • ➤ It is important to correctly identify the type of hernia based on its location and relation to previous surgical sites to ensure proper surgical planning and patient counseling.
  • ➤ Incisional hernias are related to previous surgeries, whereas epigastric, umbilical, and femoral hernias typically are not.

questions.text: A 24-year-old farm worker is rushed to the emergency department after accidental exposure to parathion. Which of the following drugs can be given to increase the activity of his acetylcholinesterase?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pralidoxime is used specifically to reactivate acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates, whereas atropine is used to manage muscarinic symptoms.
  • ➤ Pralidoxime is used specifically to reactivate acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates, whereas atropine is used to manage muscarinic symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following infants is least likely to develop hypoglycemia?

options.label: A
options.text: A baby born to a mother treated for hypoglycemia

questions.correct_answer: C. Appropriate for gestational age (AGA) baby
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neonates at risk of hypoglycemia include:
  • ➤ Neonates at risk of hypoglycemia include:
  • ➤ Neonates at risk of hypoglycemia include:
  • ➤ Birth weight <2000g Gestational age <35 weeks Small for gestational age infants (SGA): birth weight<10th percentile Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) Large for gestational age (LGA) infants: birth weight>90th percentile Neonates with Rh-hemolytic disease Neonates born to mothers receiving therapy with Propranolol/Labetolol/oral hypoglycemic agents Neonates with morphological features of growth restriction like three or more loose folds of skin around buttocks and thighs, loss of subcutaneous fat, difference of HC and CC>3cm Any sick neonate e.g, those with perinatal asphyxia, polycythemia, sepsis, shock, etc Family history of a genetic form of hypoglycemia Congenital syndromes (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedermann), abnormal physical features (e.g., midline facial malformations, microphallus) Neonates on parenteral nutrition.
  • ➤ Birth weight <2000g
  • ➤ Gestational age <35 weeks
  • ➤ Small for gestational age infants (SGA): birth weight<10th percentile
  • ➤ Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM)
  • ➤ Large for gestational age (LGA) infants: birth weight>90th percentile
  • ➤ Neonates with Rh-hemolytic disease
  • ➤ Neonates born to mothers receiving therapy with Propranolol/Labetolol/oral hypoglycemic agents
  • ➤ Neonates with morphological features of growth restriction like three or more loose folds of skin around buttocks and thighs, loss of subcutaneous fat, difference of HC and CC>3cm
  • ➤ Any sick neonate e.g, those with perinatal asphyxia, polycythemia, sepsis, shock, etc
  • ➤ Family history of a genetic form of hypoglycemia
  • ➤ Congenital syndromes (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedermann), abnormal physical features (e.g., midline facial malformations, microphallus)
  • ➤ Neonates on parenteral nutrition.

questions.text: Which gene is responsible for aiding the thymus in distinguishing self from foreign cells?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement? Ferry’s Line-corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs Stockers Line-Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of pterygium Hudson-Stahli line- visible all around the base of cone in Keratoconus Fleischer’s ring: Horizontal corneal epithelial iron line’ at the inferior one third of cornea due to aging Coat’s white ring- A form of iron deposit at the level of Bowman’s layer of cornea
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ferry's line and Stocker's line are both corneal epithelial iron lines observed in specific ocular conditions, such as filtering blebs after trabeculectomy and at the edge of pterygium, respectively. Hudson-Stahli line is not associated with keratoconus; it is a pigmentary line seen in the inferior third of the cornea in elderly individuals. Fleischer's ring is a characteristic feature of keratoconus, appearing as a horizontal brownish ring at the base of the cone in the cornea. Coat's white ring, observed at the level of Bowman's layer in the cornea, is a form of iron deposit seen in previous Iron foreign body.
  • ➤ Ferry's line and Stocker's line are both corneal epithelial iron lines observed in specific ocular conditions, such as filtering blebs after trabeculectomy and at the edge of pterygium, respectively.
  • ➤ Hudson-Stahli line is not associated with keratoconus; it is a pigmentary line seen in the inferior third of the cornea in elderly individuals.
  • ➤ Fleischer's ring is a characteristic feature of keratoconus, appearing as a horizontal brownish ring at the base of the cone in the cornea.
  • ➤ Coat's white ring, observed at the level of Bowman's layer in the cornea, is a form of iron deposit seen in previous Iron foreign body.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction. Examination reveals a vascular mass in the nasopharynx. Given this clinical presentation, the absence of Dodd's sign would be most consistent with which of the following aspects of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)?

options.label: A
options.text: JNA arises from posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: C
options.text: JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

options.label: D
options.text: JNA do not have muscular contractile part in its blood vessels

questions.correct_answer: C. JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The growth pattern of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is typically arises from the sphenopalatine foramen and expands submucosally. Recognizing this pattern is essential for differential diagnosis and understanding why certain clinical signs, such as Dodd's sign, are absent in JNA despite its size and vascularity.
  • ➤ The growth pattern of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is typically arises from the sphenopalatine foramen and expands submucosally.
  • ➤ Recognizing this pattern is essential for differential diagnosis and understanding why certain clinical signs, such as Dodd's sign, are absent in JNA despite its size and vascularity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with difficulty in speaking and swallowing. He reports that these symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past six months. Physical examination reveals atrophy and weakness of the tongue muscles. There is no sensory loss, and other cranial nerve functions are intact. His past medical history is significant for a long-standing diagnosis of a neurodegenerative disorder. Which of the following is the embryological origin of the affected muscle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occipital Myotomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intrinsic muscles of the tongue develop from the occipital myotomes , which are segments of paraxial mesoderm located in the occipital region of the embryo . These myotomes give rise to the muscle precursors that migrate into the developing tongue , forming its musculature .
  • ➤ The intrinsic muscles of the tongue develop from the occipital myotomes , which are segments of paraxial mesoderm located in the occipital region of the embryo .
  • ➤ intrinsic muscles
  • ➤ tongue
  • ➤ occipital myotomes
  • ➤ paraxial mesoderm
  • ➤ occipital region
  • ➤ embryo
  • ➤ These myotomes give rise to the muscle precursors that migrate into the developing tongue , forming its musculature .
  • ➤ muscle precursors
  • ➤ migrate
  • ➤ developing tongue
  • ➤ musculature

questions.text: Match the following types of grafts with their definitions:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • c. Allograft (1): Tissue graft from a genetically unrelated member of the same species, commonly used in organ transplantation.
  • • b. Isograft (2): Tissue graft from a genetically identical person, such as an identical twin, which carries no risk of rejection.
  • • a. Autograft (3): Tissue grafted from one part of the body to another part within the same individual, carrying the lowest risk of rejection.
  • • d. Xenograft (4): Tissue graft from a member of a different species, typically having the highest risk of rejection.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transplantation procedures involve various types of grafts depending on the source of the donor tissue. An allograft is from the same species but not genetically identical, an isograft is from an identical twin, an autograft is from the same individual, and a xenograft is from a different species.
  • ➤ Transplantation procedures involve various types of grafts depending on the source of the donor tissue.
  • ➤ An allograft is from the same species but not genetically identical, an isograft is from an identical twin, an autograft is from the same individual, and a xenograft is from a different species.

questions.text: Development of hepatic central lobular necrosis secondary to acetaminophen overdose can be prevented effectively by which of the following if given within a few hours after ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ N-acetylcysteine is the most effective treatment for preventing liver damage following an acetaminophen overdose. It works by enhancing glutathione reserves necessary to neutralize the toxic metabolites of acetaminophen. Prompt administration, ideally within 8 hours of overdose, is critical to maximize its protective effects on the liver.
  • ➤ N-acetylcysteine is the most effective treatment for preventing liver damage following an acetaminophen overdose. It works by enhancing glutathione reserves necessary to neutralize the toxic metabolites of acetaminophen.
  • ➤ Prompt administration, ideally within 8 hours of overdose, is critical to maximize its protective effects on the liver.

  • ➤ Differential Diagnosis – based on Radiological findings
  • ➤ Differential Diagnosis – based on Radiological findings
  • ➤ Rickets - Cupping and fraying of the metaphyses. Osteogenesis Imperfecta - Thin bones with multiple fracture Scurvy - 'Scorbutic rosaries' at the costochondral junctions Osteopetrosis - Increased bone density and bone within a bone appearance
  • ➤ Rickets - Cupping and fraying of the metaphyses.
  • ➤ Osteogenesis Imperfecta - Thin bones with multiple fracture

questions.text: A female patient has been diagnosed with breast cancer, evidenced by a biopsy revealing a fixed breast nodule and nipple retraction. The biopsy was positive for HER2/neu. In the immunohistochemical analysis used to detect HER2/neu, which chromogen is responsible for producing the brown color seen in the stain?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Diaminobenzidine

questions.text: True about primary open angle glaucoma is: Also k/a Chronic simple glaucoma Hypermeteropeas are more predisposed Polygenic inheritance Laser iridotomy is used for treatment Fundus examination reveals large cup
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG) is also known as chronic simple glaucoma. Myopes (nearsighted individuals) are more predisposed to POAG than hypermetropes (farsighted individuals). POAG has a polygenic inheritance pattern, indicating that multiple genes contribute to its development. Laser iridotomy is not typically used for the treatment of POAG; treatment usually involves medications, laser trabeculoplasty, or surgery. Fundus examination in POAG often reveals a large cup-to-disc ratio, indicating optic disc cupping.
  • ➤ Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG) is also known as chronic simple glaucoma.
  • ➤ Myopes (nearsighted individuals) are more predisposed to POAG than hypermetropes (farsighted individuals).
  • ➤ POAG has a polygenic inheritance pattern, indicating that multiple genes contribute to its development.
  • ➤ Laser iridotomy is not typically used for the treatment of POAG; treatment usually involves medications, laser trabeculoplasty, or surgery.
  • ➤ Fundus examination in POAG often reveals a large cup-to-disc ratio, indicating optic disc cupping.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came with bleeding per rectum and was diagnosed to have carcinoma colon. The patient underwent extended right hemicolectomy. Identify the instrument that the surgeon is using:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Monopolar cautery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When dealing with surgical procedures, the choice of the instrument for cutting and coagulation depends on the specific needs of the surgery. Monopolar cautery is widely used for its versatility and effectiveness in both tissue dissection and hemostasis. Each device has unique advantages and limitations, and the surgeon's choice will depend on the procedure's requirements, tissue type, and desired outcome of minimizing blood loss and preserving surrounding tissue integrity.
  • ➤ When dealing with surgical procedures, the choice of the instrument for cutting and coagulation depends on the specific needs of the surgery.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to difficulty running and frequent falls. His mother reports that he also has trouble getting up from a seated position on the floor. During the physical examination, a positive Gower's sign is noted, and the child uses his hands to "walk" up his body to stand. Further evaluation reveals elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels. Considering the clinical findings and history provided, as well as the muscle appearance in the legs as shown in the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Duchenne muscular dystrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The child's difficulty standing up from a sitting position, demonstrated by a positive Gower’s sign, along with elevated CPK levels, is characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)
  • ➤ The child's difficulty standing up from a sitting position, demonstrated by a positive Gower’s sign, along with elevated CPK levels, is characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)

questions.text: A 41-year-old female presents in the outpatient department reporting that she passes blood instead of urine during the night. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PIGA gene. She undergoes a series of laboratory tests including the Ham test. What is the primary abnormality detected by the Ham test?

options.label: D
options.text: Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH

questions.correct_answer: D. Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH

questions.text: An antitubercular drug that should not be given to a patient with both tuberculosis and AIDS is:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiacetazone, due to its risk of severe and potentially fatal adverse reactions, should be avoided in HIV-positive patients, demonstrating the importance of selecting antitubercular therapy that accounts for both efficacy and safety in the context of the patient’s overall health status.
  • ➤ Thiacetazone, due to its risk of severe and potentially fatal adverse reactions, should be avoided in HIV-positive patients, demonstrating the importance of selecting antitubercular therapy that accounts for both efficacy and safety in the context of the patient’s overall health status.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man develops acute renal failure five days following an episode of diarrhea. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia and anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10 g/dL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HUS is a critical condition that often presents with a triad of acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, typically following a diarrheal illness caused by certain strains of bacteria. Prompt recognition and management of HUS are vital due to its potential for rapid progression and serious complications.
  • ➤ HUS is a critical condition that often presents with a triad of acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, typically following a diarrheal illness caused by certain strains of bacteria.
  • ➤ Prompt recognition and management of HUS are vital due to its potential for rapid progression and serious complications.

questions.text: A patient comes to the trauma centre with an injury as shown in the image. Which of the following steps should not be done during the initial evaluation of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Removal of foreign body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visual acuity testing, conducting a primary survey, and administering antibiotics are essential steps in the initial evaluation and management of eye injuries. However, in the presence of a foreign body penetrating into the globe, no attempt should be made to remove it prior to ophthalmic consultation to avoid exacerbating the damage.
  • ➤ Visual acuity testing, conducting a primary survey, and administering antibiotics are essential steps in the initial evaluation and management of eye injuries.
  • ➤ However, in the presence of a foreign body penetrating into the globe, no attempt should be made to remove it prior to ophthalmic consultation to avoid exacerbating the damage.

questions.text: In the context of Friedreich's Ataxia, which of the following statements is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Progressive Ataxia is the most common presentation

options.label: D
options.text: Extensor plantar with brisk lower limb reflexes

questions.correct_answer: D. Extensor plantar with brisk lower limb reflexes
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical features of Friedreich's Ataxia are that loss of deep tendon reflexes are characteristic, contrasting with the incorrect statement that patients would present with brisk reflexes.
  • ➤ The clinical features of Friedreich's Ataxia are that loss of deep tendon reflexes are characteristic, contrasting with the incorrect statement that patients would present with brisk reflexes.

questions.text: A patient has undergone a surgical procedure as depicted in the image below. Postoperatively, an Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) test was conducted with the sound stimulus delivered directly to the processor from the outside, bypassing the ear canal and earphone. Based on this setup, which waves in the ABR test would found to be abnormal?

options.label: C
options.text: Waves III, IV, V, VI & VII

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Waves I & II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auditory Brainstem Implants (ABI) is that post-implantation, an Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) test will not show waves I and II, which are associated with the auditory nerve, because ABIs bypass the damaged auditory nerve and directly stimulate the brainstem.
  • ➤ Auditory Brainstem Implants (ABI) is that post-implantation, an Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) test will not show waves I and II, which are associated with the auditory nerve, because ABIs bypass the damaged auditory nerve and directly stimulate the brainstem.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient with diabetes on metformin therapy reports inadequate glycemic control despite an increased dosage. The patient has a personal history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer. Preferring to avoid injectable medications, which oral agent should be considered next for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Canagliflozin is an effective oral agent that can be used in patients who are obese and wish to avoid injections, with caution exercised in patients with a risk of genitourinary infections.
  • ➤ Canagliflozin is an effective oral agent that can be used in patients who are obese and wish to avoid injections, with caution exercised in patients with a risk of genitourinary infections.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy was diagnosed with urethral stricture. He underwent visual internal urethrotomy in the lithotomy position with stirrups supporting both popliteal fossa and proximal parts of tibia. No ankle support was used. On the first postoperative day, the patient complained of decreased sensation on the lateral aspect of right leg, the lateral border of his right foot and difficulty in dorsiflexion of the right foot due to compression of a particular nerve of the lower limb. Which of the following muscles is supplied by the nerve involved in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Extensor Digitorum Longus

questions.text: The below-given instrument is commonly inserted in and used for:

options.label: A
options.text: Drainage of postoperative fluids in abdomen

options.label: C
options.text: Drainage of bile in common bile duct ( CBD)

options.label: D
options.text: Drainage of pus from abscess cavities

questions.correct_answer: C. Drainage of bile in common bile duct ( CBD)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Drainage of bile in common bile duct (CBD)

questions.text: A physician wants to prescribe a medication to alkalinize a patient's urine for the treatment of uric acid kidney stones. Which medication should be chosen?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetazolamide is effective for alkalinizing the urine due to its inhibition of carbonic anhydrase, which decreases reabsorption of bicarbonate in the kidneys, thereby promoting its excretion.
  • ➤ Acetazolamide is effective for alkalinizing the urine due to its inhibition of carbonic anhydrase, which decreases reabsorption of bicarbonate in the kidneys, thereby promoting its excretion.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The parents are first-time parents and are eager to know about their child's growth and development milestones. The pediatrician measures the infant's head circumference and compares it with the measurement taken at birth. By how much does the head circumference typically increase during the first three months of life?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 2 cm

questions.text: A 56-year-old female diagnosed with breast carcinoma is prescribed trastuzumab (Herceptin). Which of the following statements about this drug is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an antibody produced entirely from mouse containing no human component.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting her-2 antigen.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a monoclonal antibody containing only human components.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting her-2 antigen.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trastuzumab as a humanized monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.
  • ➤ Trastuzumab as a humanized monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with a two-month history of persistent cough and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. She additionally reports experiencing dry eyes and the appearance of nodules on her arm skin. What type of granuloma is likely to be identified in the lymph node biopsy of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Naked granulomas are the hallmark finding in sarcoidosis biopsies, specifically characterized by their lack of surrounding lymphocytes, helping to diagnose this systemic granulomatous condition.
  • ➤ Naked granulomas are the hallmark finding in sarcoidosis biopsies, specifically characterized by their lack of surrounding lymphocytes, helping to diagnose this systemic granulomatous condition.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is evaluated for generalized edema and significant proteinuria, with normal appearance of the kidneys on light microscopy. Considering his clinical and laboratory findings, what finding is most likely to be observed on electron microscopy of his kidney biopsy?

options.label: A
options.text: Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells

options.label: C
options.text: Deposition of electron dense material in the basement membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The minimal change disease, which typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children, is characterized by the effacement or fusion of podocyte foot processes seen on electron microscopy, despite normal-appearing kidneys on light microscopy.
  • ➤ The minimal change disease, which typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children, is characterized by the effacement or fusion of podocyte foot processes seen on electron microscopy, despite normal-appearing kidneys on light microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Tacrolimus is NOT TRUE?

options.label: B
options.text: It is indicated for the prophylaxis of organ transplant rejection

options.label: C
options.text: Glucose intolerance is a well-recognized side effect

options.label: D
options.text: It can be safely administered with any nephrotoxic drug

questions.correct_answer: D. It can be safely administered with any nephrotoxic drug
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tacrolimus is a critical medication in preventing organ transplant rejection, its concomitant use with other nephrotoxic agents can significantly increase the risk of renal dysfunction.
  • ➤ Tacrolimus is a critical medication in preventing organ transplant rejection, its concomitant use with other nephrotoxic agents can significantly increase the risk of renal dysfunction.

questions.text: The following test is used for the assessment of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stereopsis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stereopsis testing assesses the ability to perceive depth and three-dimensional structure through binocular vision, which involves presenting slightly different images to each eye and analyzing how well the brain fuses them into a single three-dimensional image. Color vision, visual field, and visual acuity testing are separate assessments that evaluate different aspects of vision, including color perception, peripheral vision, and visual clarity, respectively.
  • ➤ Stereopsis testing assesses the ability to perceive depth and three-dimensional structure through binocular vision, which involves presenting slightly different images to each eye and analyzing how well the brain fuses them into a single three-dimensional image.
  • ➤ Color vision, visual field, and visual acuity testing are separate assessments that evaluate different aspects of vision, including color perception, peripheral vision, and visual clarity, respectively.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with significant weight gain, menstrual irregularities including recent amenorrhea, and newly diagnosed hypertension. To evaluate the underlying cause of her symptoms, which of the following tests would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dexamethasone suppression test (Dexa suppression test) is pivotal in diagnosing Cushing's syndrome as it assesses the adrenal glands' response to dexamethasone, specifically measuring whether cortisol production is adequately suppressed.
  • ➤ The dexamethasone suppression test (Dexa suppression test) is pivotal in diagnosing Cushing's syndrome as it assesses the adrenal glands' response to dexamethasone, specifically measuring whether cortisol production is adequately suppressed.

questions.text: A patient presented with right sided hardness of hearing. Otoendoscopy and pure tone audiometry were given below. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the condition in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Transformer ratio is decreased after surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Stapedial reflex is intact after surgery

options.label: C
options.text: The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 1 st pharyngeal arch

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Surgery is contraindicated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis - Presence of Schwartz's sign, a reddish or pinkish hue of the stapes due to active otosclerosis, is a contraindication for surgery due to the risk of excessive bleeding and the active state of the disease.
  • ➤ Otosclerosis - Presence of Schwartz's sign, a reddish or pinkish hue of the stapes due to active otosclerosis, is a contraindication for surgery due to the risk of excessive bleeding and the active state of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following anemia causes is associated with a hypoplastic bone marrow?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fanconi's Anemia is a cause of aplastic anemia, which is associated with a hypoplastic marrow. This contrasts with conditions like PNH, where hemolysis is the mechanism of anemia, or myelofibrosis, which involves fibrotic changes within the marrow.
  • ➤ Fanconi's Anemia is a cause of aplastic anemia, which is associated with a hypoplastic marrow.
  • ➤ This contrasts with conditions like PNH, where hemolysis is the mechanism of anemia, or myelofibrosis, which involves fibrotic changes within the marrow.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness and loss of sensation on the right side of his body. Neurological examination reveals contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss affecting the face, arm, and leg. Which of the following is the most common cause of stroke involving the Internal Capsule?

options.label: B
options.text: Direct branches of internal carotid artery

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: C. Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral striate arteries are the primary suppliers of blood to the internal capsule . Due to their small size and critical location , these arteries are particularly susceptible to hypertension-induced damage , leading to lacunar strokes , which often occur in the internal capsule.
  • ➤ The lateral striate arteries are the primary suppliers of blood to the internal capsule .
  • ➤ primary suppliers
  • ➤ blood
  • ➤ internal capsule
  • ➤ Due to their small size and critical location , these arteries are particularly susceptible to hypertension-induced damage , leading to lacunar strokes , which often occur in the internal capsule.
  • ➤ small size
  • ➤ critical location
  • ➤ susceptible
  • ➤ hypertension-induced damage
  • ➤ lacunar strokes

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to OPD with severe cachexia and dysphagia to solids. Endoscopy shows lumen occluding growth at mid esophagus. While he is being investigated, you start him on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). After one day, the patient gets seizures and tetany. What likely abnormality is the most likely to be responsible for the above event?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypophosphatemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sudden onset of seizures and tetany in a patient who has just started on TPN is most likely due to hypophosphatemia, a key feature of refeeding syndrome, which requires careful management and monitoring of electrolyte levels during the initiation of nutrition in malnourished patients.
  • ➤ The sudden onset of seizures and tetany in a patient who has just started on TPN is most likely due to hypophosphatemia, a key feature of refeeding syndrome, which requires careful management and monitoring of electrolyte levels during the initiation of nutrition in malnourished patients.
